articles.title: NOVEMBER, 1971
articles.summary: This document lists the officers for an organization in November 1971. It includes the names, titles (President, Vice-President, Secretary, Treasurer), and phone numbers for Dave Erickson, Tom Halliday, Jerry Rattley, and Emmet Murphy.

articles.title: NOVEMBER 5 - REGULAR MEETING - EQUIPMENT NIGHT
articles.summary: The article announces a regular 'Equipment Night' meeting scheduled for November 5 at 8 p.m. at Community Bank. Members are encouraged to bring their astronomy equipment, such as telescopes, eyepieces, binoculars, and maps, to discuss them, exchange ideas, and potentially buy, sell, or swap items. The event is an annual tradition aimed at fostering community and knowledge sharing.

articles.title: NOVEMBER 12 - PLANNING MEETING
articles.summary: A planning meeting is scheduled for November 12 at 8 p.m. at Norman Wild's residence in San Jose. Attendees can call 252-9366 for directions to the location at 7557 Orange Blossom Drive.

articles.title: NOVEMBER 13 & 20 - STARPARTIES
articles.summary: Starparties are scheduled for November 13 and November 20 at the SJAA Observatory Site, commencing at dusk, provided weather conditions are favorable. Attendees are advised to contact Dave at 269-4838 for further details and specifics regarding these events.

articles.title: DECEMBER 3 - MORRISON LECTURE
articles.summary: A special Morrison Lecture featuring Dr. David Cudaback of UC Berkeley will be held on December 3rd at West Valley College, focusing on "High Altitude Astronomy" and including a planetarium show. This event replaces the regular December meeting and is funded by an Astronomical Society of the Pacific endowment, requiring members to attend and assist with publicity to ensure good attendance.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK IN OCTOBER
articles.summary: The Fremont Peak event scheduled for October 16 was cancelled due to threatening weather conditions, specifically light rain, leading to zero attendance. An announcement regarding its potential rescheduling will be made at the next meeting.

articles.title: UPCOMING EVENTS (In addition to page 1)
articles.summary: This document lists upcoming events from December to March, including regular meetings with talks on various astronomical topics such as double stars, Pluto, binaries, spectroscopy, and optics, alongside planning meetings and a star party. Additionally, it features a classified ad for a Minolta slide projector for sale.

articles.title: ORBITS OF VISUAL BINARY STARS--part 1
articles.summary: This article, 'ORBITS OF VISUAL BINARY STARS--part 1,' by Jerry Rattley, provides detailed orbital elements and observational information for three specific visual binary stars: Struve 3062 (π3062 Cas), 48 Cassiopeiae, and Struve 3052 (Σ3050 And). For each binary, the author presents its celestial location, component characteristics (magnitude, spectral class), future separation predictions (apastron/periastron), and ephemeris data (position angle and separation), alongside recommendations for observing with specific telescope apertures.

articles.title: MEMBERSHIP LIST
articles.summary: This document is a membership list, dated August 29, 1971, providing contact information for individuals. It includes names, addresses, and phone numbers for members located across various cities in California, primarily in the San Francisco Bay Area.

articles.title: MEMBERSHIP LIST (PAGE 2)
articles.summary: This document is the second page of a membership list, detailing names, addresses, and phone numbers for various individuals. It serves as a directory of members, with some contact information, particularly phone numbers, indicated as potentially outdated or no longer valid.

articles.title: REVISED MAP TO THE SJAA OBSERVATORY SITE
articles.summary: This document provides revised, detailed driving directions and distances to the SJAA Observatory Site, starting from Highway 17 and Summit Road. It lists 12 distinct points along the route with specific mileage between them and turn instructions. The total distance from Summit Road to the observatory is 6.65 miles, with the measurements taken by Rich Kittler and Dave Erickson in 1971.
